about.content: Hi! My name is Dalton Craven. I'm a software engineer and recent graduate of the University of South Carolina. I'm a big proponent of web accessibility and localization techniques to ensure that the web stays open for all.

journey.content1: I've always been fascinated by technology and the way it can be used to solve problems. I was first introduced to the world of computer science in high school through Hack Club, a network of student-run programming organizations. I then went on to study both theoretical and applied computer science at the University of South Carolina, where I graduated summa cum laude with a B.S.C.S. in Computer Science.
journey.content2: During my time at USC, I had the opportunity to study abroad in Paris and intern at Qantev, a French tech start-up. These experiences were invaluable in shaping my worldview and broadening my horizons. I was able to experience a new culture, learn a new language, and make lifelong friends. I also gained a deeper appreciation for the importance of localization and accessibility in software development.
journey.content3: I'm currently back in Paris working as a full-stack software engineer at Qantev, where I'm helping to build a platform that will revolutionize the way insurance companies manage their data. I'm also working on a few personal projects, including a website for my photography hobby and a toolkit for ballroom dance.

content1.title: Wordification: A New Way of Teaching English Spelling Patterns
content1.description: Wordification is a set of online games designed to teach spelling through the linkage of phonemes and graphemes, encouraging students to learn spelling rules phonetically rather than memorizing static spelling lists. Wordification is currently in the proof-of-concept stage, but our team is eagerly looking forward to conducting real-world, peer-reviewed trials with students soon. We recently submitted a research paper to a paper about Wordification to the 19th International Conference on Frontiers in Education: Computer Science & Computer Engineering, which was accepted for publication — we're excited about presenting our work ths July. Wordification is built with Redwood and Typescript, and is visible on GitHub.

content2.title: DKMS: Social Media Features for Spotify
content2.description: For my senior capstone project, I led a team of five in designing and implementing a unique application — one that enriches the Spotify experience by integrating social media features. Given the significant workload, I assumed multiple roles — developer, devops manager, and scrum master. The final product was a full-stack web application built with Next.js, Typescript, Firestore, and the Spotify Web SDK. Some key features included the ability to dynamically load content, tailored recommendations based on a user's listening activity, and audio analysis of songs, albums, artists, and playlists. The project is deployed on Vercel, and the code is visible on GitHub.
